sections.title: What Is Digital Identity?
sections.content:
Your digital identity is who you are online. It includes your usernames, photos, posts, and everything you share on the internet.

Your digital identity is like a second version of you that lives online. This online version is seen by friends, family, and sometimes strangers.

Your digital identity can be different from who you are in person. Some people act differently online. It's important to be true to yourself both online and offline.

keyTerms.digital identity: Who you are and how you appear on the internet
keyTerms.username: A name you choose to use on websites and apps
keyTerms.profile: Information about you shown on websites or apps

sections.title: Your Digital Footprint
sections.content:
Everything you do online leaves a mark called a digital footprint. This includes:
- Posts and comments you make
- Photos and videos you share
- Websites you visit
- Things you search for
- Messages you send

Your digital footprint stays around for a long time. Even if you delete something, it might still exist somewhere. Others may have saved it or taken screenshots.

Think of the internet like a permanent marker, not a pencil. What you write is hard to erase.

keyTerms.digital footprint: The trail of information you leave behind when you use the internet
keyTerms.screenshot: A picture of what's on your screen

sections.title: Privacy Online
sections.content:
Privacy means keeping some things to yourself. Online privacy is about controlling what information others can see about you.

Some things should stay private:
- Your full name and address
- Your phone number
- Your school name
- Passwords
- Private family information

Most apps and websites have privacy settings. These let you choose who can see your posts. Ask a trusted adult to help you set these up.

Be careful about who you share information with online. Not everyone who seems friendly is safe.

keyTerms.privacy: The right to keep things to yourself
keyTerms.privacy settings: Controls that let you choose who sees your information

sections.title: Staying Safe Online
sections.content:
Here are simple ways to stay safe online:

1. Think before you post - Would you be happy if your family saw this?
2. Use strong passwords - Don't share them with friends
3. Be careful with strangers - Not everyone online is who they say they are
4. Talk to trusted adults - If something makes you uncomfortable, tell someone
5. Be kind - Treat others the way you want to be treated

If something happens online that scares or upsets you, it's not your fault. Talk to a parent, teacher, or another adult you trust.

In Australia, the eSafety Commissioner helps with online safety problems. You can report cyberbullying and other issues to them.

keyTerms.cyberbullying: Using the internet to be mean to or hurt someone
keyTerms.eSafety Commissioner: An Australian organisation that helps with online safety

caseStudy.title: Jake's Photo Problem
caseStudy.scenario: Jake took a funny photo of his friend Marcus falling over at school. He thought it was hilarious and posted it online without asking Marcus. The photo spread quickly, and now lots of people are laughing at Marcus. Marcus is really upset and embarrassed.

characters.name: Jake
characters.background: Didn't think about how Marcus would feel before posting

characters.name: Marcus
characters.background: Embarrassed that so many people have seen the photo

questions.question: What mistake did Jake make?
questions.guidanceNote: Identify that Jake didn't ask permission before posting

questions.question: How might Marcus be feeling? Why?
questions.guidanceNote: Discuss embarrassment and loss of control over one's image

questions.question: What should Jake do now?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider apologising and deleting the post

caseStudy.followUp: Jake apologised to Marcus and deleted the post. He learned to always ask before sharing photos of others. Some people still had screenshots, which taught Jake that online posts are hard to fully remove.

sections.title: Building Your Digital Identity
sections.content:
Your digital identity is built over time through everything you do online. It includes your profiles on social media, the content you create and share, and how you interact with others.

Your digital identity has several parts:
- Your chosen usernames and profile pictures
- The content you post (photos, videos, comments)
- The pages and people you follow
- The groups you join
- How you communicate with others

Unlike your offline identity, your digital identity is visible to many people at once. It can be seen by friends, family, future employers, and even strangers. This makes it important to think carefully about what you share.

Your digital identity should reflect who you really are. Being authentic online means showing your real interests and personality while still protecting your privacy.

keyTerms.digital identity: The online representation of who you are built through your internet activity
keyTerms.authentic: Being true to yourself rather than pretending to be someone else
keyTerms.online presence: How you appear and are perceived across different online platforms

sections.title: Active and Passive Digital Footprints
sections.content:
Your digital footprint has two types: active and passive.

Active digital footprint includes things you deliberately share:
- Social media posts
- Photos you upload
- Comments you write
- Profiles you create
- Emails you send

Passive digital footprint is information collected without you actively sharing it:
- Websites tracking which pages you visit
- Apps collecting your location data
- Search engines recording your searches
- Cookies tracking your browsing habits

Many apps and websites collect passive data to personalise ads or services. You often agree to this without realising when you accept terms and conditions.

Understanding both types of footprints helps you make better decisions about what you share and which apps you use.

keyTerms.cookies: Small files that websites use to track your activity

sections.title: Managing Your Online Reputation
sections.content:
Your online reputation is what people think about you based on your digital presence. This reputation can affect your friendships, school opportunities, and even future jobs.

To manage your reputation:

1. Think about your audience - Different platforms have different audiences. What's appropriate for friends might not be appropriate for a wider audience.

2. Google yourself - Search your name to see what comes up. You might be surprised by what's publicly visible.

3. Review privacy settings - Check settings on all your accounts. Make sure only the right people can see your posts.

4. Be consistent - Your online behaviour should match the person you want to be known as.

5. Create positive content - Share achievements, interests, and thoughtful comments to build a positive reputation.

Remember that screenshots last forever. Even disappearing messages can be saved by others.

keyTerms.online reputation: What others think about you based on your digital presence
keyTerms.audience: The people who see your online content

sections.title: Privacy Risks and Protection
sections.content:
There are several privacy risks online that you should be aware of:

Oversharing: Posting too much personal information can make you vulnerable. Even innocent details can be combined to learn a lot about you.

Location sharing: Many apps track and share your location. This can reveal your daily routines and where you spend time.

Phishing: Scammers try to trick you into giving away personal information through fake websites or messages.

Identity theft: If someone gets enough personal information, they can pretend to be you online.

To protect yourself:
- Use strong, unique passwords for each account
- Enable two-factor authentication when available
- Review app permissions regularly
- Don't click suspicious links
- Be careful what you share, even in private messages

The eSafety Commissioner in Australia provides resources and help for young people dealing with online safety issues.

keyTerms.oversharing: Posting too much personal information online
keyTerms.phishing: Tricks used to steal personal information
keyTerms.two-factor authentication: An extra security step when logging into accounts

caseStudy.title: The Party Post Problem
caseStudy.scenario: Sophie posted photos from a friend's party on her public Instagram account. One photo showed her friend Emma looking silly with cake on her face. Another showed the inside of Emma's house, including some expensive items. Emma's parents were upset because they hadn't given permission, and they were worried about security. Some older students also started making fun of Emma because of the cake photo.

characters.name: Sophie
characters.background: Didn't think about privacy implications when posting

characters.name: Emma
characters.background: Embarrassed by the photo and worried about family privacy

questions.question: What privacy issues are involved in this situation?
questions.guidanceNote: Identify both personal privacy (Emma's photo) and family/security privacy

questions.question: What digital footprint has Sophie created for herself and for Emma?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider how this affects both people's online reputations

questions.question: What steps should Sophie take now, and what should she do differently in the future?
questions.guidanceNote: Include apologising, deleting posts, and learning to ask permission

caseStudy.followUp: Sophie deleted the photos and apologised to Emma and her family. She learned to ask permission before posting photos of others or their homes. She also set her account to private so only approved followers could see her posts.

remember.question: Explain the difference between active and passive digital footprints.
remember.sampleAnswer: An active digital footprint is information you deliberately share, like posts and photos. A passive digital footprint is information collected about you automatically, like websites tracking your browsing or apps collecting your location.

understand.question: Why is it important to manage your online reputation?
understand.sampleAnswer: Managing your online reputation is important because what people see about you online affects how they think of you. This can impact friendships, school opportunities, and even future job prospects. Your online reputation can last for years, so building a positive one early is valuable.

apply.question: Create a checklist of five things you would do to protect your privacy online.
apply.sampleAnswer: My privacy protection checklist: 1) Use strong, unique passwords for each account. 2) Check privacy settings on all social media accounts. 3) Turn off location sharing when not needed. 4) Think carefully before accepting friend requests from strangers. 5) Be careful about what personal information I share in posts and profiles.

analyse.question: Compare the privacy risks of using a public social media account versus a private one.
analyse.sampleAnswer: A public account means anyone can see your posts, follow you, and learn about you. This increases risks of strangers seeing personal information, screenshots being taken without your knowledge, and content being shared widely. A private account limits viewers to approved followers, giving you more control. However, even private accounts have risks - followers can still screenshot content, and the platform itself collects your data.

unistructural.question: What is an online reputation?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: An online reputation is what others think about you based on your digital presence.

multistructural.question: List three ways to protect your privacy online.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Three ways to protect privacy are: using strong unique passwords, reviewing app permissions, and being careful about what personal information you share.

relational.question: Explain how your active digital footprint affects your online reputation.
relational.sampleAnswer: My active digital footprint directly shapes my online reputation because it includes everything I choose to post and share. The comments I write, photos I upload, and groups I join all show others who I am. Positive, thoughtful posts build a good reputation, while negative or thoughtless posts can damage how others see me. Since this content stays online long-term, my past choices continue affecting my reputation.

extendedAbstract.question: Predict how changes in technology might affect digital privacy in the future.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: As technology advances, digital privacy will face new challenges. Facial recognition could make it harder to be anonymous in photos. Improved AI might analyse our posts to learn about our personalities and predict our behaviour. Smart devices in our homes could collect more passive data about our daily lives. However, technology might also provide better privacy tools, like improved encryption. People will need to become more educated about digital privacy and may need new laws to protect them. The balance between convenience and privacy will become an increasingly important choice.

prompts: When was the last time you checked your privacy settings? What did you find?
How do you decide what to share online versus what to keep private?
Has anything you posted online ever had unexpected consequences?
What would someone learn about you from your digital footprint?

sections.title: The Relationship Between Online and Offline Identity
sections.content:
Your online identity and offline identity are interconnected. What you do online affects how people see you in person, and your real-world experiences shape what you share online.

For many young people, the distinction between online and offline life is blurring. Social media is not separate from 'real life' - it's part of it. Friendships are maintained through messaging apps, memories are shared through photos, and communities form around shared interests online.

This creates both opportunities and challenges. You can express different aspects of your identity online, connect with like-minded people, and explore interests. However, you also need to navigate different audiences, manage your reputation across platforms, and deal with the permanence of digital content.

Identity development in the digital age involves finding authenticity while maintaining appropriate boundaries. Being 'real' online doesn't mean sharing everything - it means being genuine in what you do share while protecting your privacy and wellbeing.

keyTerms.online identity: How you present yourself and are perceived in digital spaces
keyTerms.offline identity: Who you are in face-to-face interactions and the physical world
keyTerms.authenticity: Being genuine and true to yourself in how you present yourself

sections.title: Digital Identity and Wellbeing
sections.content:
Your relationship with your digital identity significantly affects your mental health and wellbeing.

Positive impacts can include:
- Connecting with supportive communities
- Expressing yourself creatively
- Finding others with shared experiences
- Building confidence through positive feedback
- Maintaining friendships across distances

Negative impacts can include:
- Comparing yourself unfavourably to others' curated posts
- Experiencing cyberbullying or online harassment
- Feeling pressure to present a 'perfect' image
- Anxiety about likes, followers, and engagement
- Spending excessive time managing your online presence

Social comparison is particularly significant. People typically share highlights of their lives online, not everyday moments or struggles. Comparing your real life to others' curated content can lead to feelings of inadequacy.

Developing a healthy relationship with your digital identity involves recognising that online representations are partial, setting boundaries around social media use, and focusing on genuine connection rather than metrics.

keyTerms.social comparison: Evaluating yourself by comparing to others
keyTerms.curated content: Carefully selected content that presents a particular image
keyTerms.digital wellbeing: Having a healthy relationship with technology and online spaces

sections.title: Curating Your Digital Presence
sections.content:
Curation means thoughtfully selecting what to share online. Effective curation helps you build a positive digital identity while protecting your privacy.

Strategies for thoughtful curation:

1. Consider your audience: Different platforms have different audiences. A post appropriate for close friends might not suit a wider network. Use privacy settings and separate accounts if needed.

2. Think long-term: Before posting, consider how this might look in five years. Would you want future employers, universities, or partners to see this?

3. Balance authenticity and privacy: Being genuine doesn't mean oversharing. You can share your interests and personality while keeping some things private.

4. Be consistent across platforms: Your digital identity spans multiple platforms. Inconsistency can create confusion or raise questions about your authenticity.

5. Regular review: Periodically review old posts and remove content that no longer represents you. While nothing is ever truly gone from the internet, reducing outdated content helps.

6. Create positive content: Actively share content that represents your best self - your achievements, interests, thoughtful opinions, and creative work.

keyTerms.curation: The thoughtful selection and presentation of content
keyTerms.digital literacy: The ability to effectively and critically navigate digital environments

sections.title: Algorithms, Filter Bubbles, and Identity
sections.content:
Social media algorithms significantly shape your online experience and can influence your identity development.

Algorithms are computer programs that decide what content you see. They're designed to show you content you'll engage with, based on your past behaviour. While this can seem helpful, it creates several issues:

Filter bubbles: Algorithms tend to show you content similar to what you've engaged with before. This can create 'filter bubbles' where you mainly see perspectives that reinforce your existing views.

Echo chambers: Related to filter bubbles, echo chambers occur when you're surrounded by people who share your opinions, making alternative viewpoints seem extreme or wrong.

Content influence on identity: The content you consume shapes how you think about yourself. If algorithms push certain beauty standards, lifestyles, or values, these can influence your self-perception and goals.

Engagement-driven design: Platforms are designed to maximise your time on them. This can lead to compulsive checking, FOMO (fear of missing out), and unhealthy usage patterns.

Developing critical awareness of algorithms helps you take more control of your digital experience. You can actively seek diverse perspectives, limit time on algorithmically-driven platforms, and question why certain content appears in your feed.

keyTerms.algorithm: A computer program that decides what content to show you
keyTerms.filter bubble: A situation where algorithms limit you to content similar to what you've seen before
keyTerms.echo chamber: An environment where your existing views are constantly reinforced
keyTerms.FOMO: Fear of missing out - anxiety about not being included in experiences

caseStudy.title: The Influencer Dilemma
caseStudy.scenario: Mia has built a following of 5,000 people on social media by posting about fashion and lifestyle. A company offers to pay her to promote a weight loss product. The money would be helpful, and the product isn't obviously harmful, but Mia knows some of her followers are young and might be influenced. She also isn't sure the product works. Her friends say 'everyone does sponsored posts' and it's just business. Mia feels conflicted between the opportunity and her values.

characters.name: Mia
characters.background: Built an online following around fashion and lifestyle content

questions.question: How does this situation relate to Mia's digital identity and the identity she's built with her followers?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider authenticity, trust, and the responsibility that comes with influence

questions.question: What ethical considerations should Mia think about before accepting or declining?
questions.guidanceNote: Include audience vulnerability, truthfulness, values alignment, and long-term reputation

questions.question: How might accepting or declining this offer affect Mia's online and offline identity?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider impact on reputation, self-perception, and values consistency

questions.question: What advice would you give Mia?
questions.guidanceNote: Look for balanced consideration of multiple factors

caseStudy.followUp: Mia decided to decline the offer. She felt that promoting a product she wasn't sure about would damage her authenticity and could negatively influence young followers. She later received other sponsorship offers from brands that aligned better with her values, showing that maintaining her integrity paid off in the long run.

remember.question: Define 'filter bubble' and 'echo chamber' in relation to social media.
remember.sampleAnswer: A filter bubble is a situation where algorithms limit the content you see to things similar to what you've engaged with before, restricting your exposure to diverse perspectives. An echo chamber is an environment where your existing views are constantly reinforced by people who share your opinions, making alternative viewpoints seem extreme or wrong.

understand.question: Explain how social comparison on social media can affect wellbeing.
understand.sampleAnswer: Social comparison on social media can negatively affect wellbeing because people typically share curated highlights of their lives, not everyday struggles. When we compare our real lives to others' best moments, we can feel inadequate or unsuccessful. This comparison can lead to decreased self-esteem, anxiety, depression, and unrealistic expectations for ourselves. The constant exposure to idealised images and lifestyles can make our own lives seem less satisfying.

apply.question: Design a plan for curating your digital presence that balances authenticity with privacy.
apply.sampleAnswer: My curation plan: 1) Separate accounts for different audiences - a private account for close friends and a more public profile for wider connections. 2) Before posting, I'll ask: Does this represent who I really am? Would I be comfortable with anyone seeing this in five years? 3) Share my genuine interests and achievements without revealing sensitive personal information. 4) Monthly review of old posts to remove content that no longer represents me. 5) Engage thoughtfully with others rather than seeking validation through metrics. 6) Be honest about sponsorships or influences on my content.

analyse.question: Analyse how algorithms might influence identity development in adolescents.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Algorithms can significantly influence adolescent identity development through several mechanisms. By repeatedly showing certain content types, algorithms shape what young people see as normal, desirable, or important. Beauty and fitness content can influence body image; lifestyle content can shape aspirational goals; opinion content can influence political and social views. Because adolescence is a time of identity exploration, the content consumed can strongly influence which identities seem available or appealing. Filter bubbles can limit exposure to diverse role models and ways of living. Additionally, engagement-focused design can create unhealthy relationships with validation-seeking behaviour, where self-worth becomes tied to online metrics.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that 'your online identity isn't really you.'
evaluate.sampleAnswer: This claim is partially true but oversimplified. Online identity is a curated representation - we select what to share and how to present ourselves. In this sense, it's not the complete 'real' person. However, saying it 'isn't really you' goes too far. What we choose to share, how we interact, and the communities we join all reflect genuine aspects of who we are. Our online actions have real consequences and express real values. For many people, online spaces allow authentic expression that might be difficult offline. The better framing is that online identity is one part of a complete identity - neither more nor less 'real' than other aspects, but necessarily partial and context-dependent.

create.question: Create guidelines for a social media platform that would support healthy digital identity development.
create.sampleAnswer: Platform Guidelines for Healthy Digital Identity: 1) Transparency about algorithms - show users why content appears in their feed and allow them to adjust. 2) Diversity tools - actively surface diverse perspectives to counter filter bubbles. 3) Wellbeing features - usage reminders, easy access to break features, no infinite scroll. 4) Age-appropriate design - stronger privacy defaults for young users, limitations on metrics visibility. 5) Anti-comparison features - option to hide like counts and follower numbers. 6) Authentication without surveillance - verify age and identity without tracking all activity. 7) Education integration - in-app learning about digital literacy and wellbeing. 8) Positive engagement incentives - reward thoughtful interaction over controversial engagement.

unistructural.question: What is digital wellbeing?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Digital wellbeing is having a healthy relationship with technology and online spaces.

multistructural.question: List three ways social media can positively impact identity development and three ways it can negatively impact it.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Positive impacts: 1) Connecting with supportive communities who share your interests or experiences, 2) Opportunities for creative self-expression, 3) Maintaining friendships across distances. Negative impacts: 1) Unhealthy social comparison to curated content, 2) Pressure to present a 'perfect' image, 3) Anxiety about likes and followers affecting self-worth.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between algorithms, filter bubbles, and identity development.
relational.sampleAnswer: Algorithms, filter bubbles, and identity development are interconnected. Algorithms analyse our past behaviour and show us similar content, creating filter bubbles where we mainly see content that reinforces our existing interests and views. During identity development, the content we consume shapes how we see ourselves and the world. When filter bubbles limit our exposure to diverse perspectives, they can narrow our sense of what identities are possible or desirable. We may adopt the values and aesthetics we're repeatedly shown without realising alternatives exist. Breaking out of filter bubbles requires deliberate effort to seek diverse content and critically evaluate what we're being shown.

extendedAbstract.question: Evaluate how digital identity might reshape traditional understandings of authenticity and self-presentation.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: Digital identity challenges traditional notions of authenticity in several ways. Traditionally, authenticity meant being consistently 'yourself' - presenting the same person across contexts. Digital spaces complicate this because we naturally present differently across platforms with different audiences, yet all these presentations are 'us.' The curated nature of digital content doesn't necessarily mean inauthenticity - selecting what to share is part of all human communication. However, digital spaces introduce new pressures: the permanence of content, the scale of audiences, and algorithmic incentives for certain types of expression. A more nuanced understanding of authenticity might focus on consistency with values rather than identical self-presentation, honesty about the partial nature of any representation, and alignment between online expressions and offline actions. Digital identity may ultimately expand rather than diminish authenticity by allowing expression of aspects of self that face-to-face contexts constrain.

How do you think social media algorithms have influenced your interests or views?
What boundaries do you set between your online and offline life? Are they working?
How does engaging with social media affect your mood and wellbeing?

sections.title: Theoretical Perspectives on Digital Identity
sections.content:
Understanding digital identity requires theoretical frameworks that can account for the unique features of online environments.

Erving Goffman's dramaturgical theory, originally about face-to-face interaction, applies to digital contexts. Goffman saw social life as performance, with 'front stage' behaviour for audiences and 'back stage' for private moments. Social media intensifies this by creating permanent records of performances, blurring front and back stage boundaries, and multiplying our audiences.

Sherry Turkle's work on identity in digital spaces suggests that online environments allow for experimentation with multiple identities. While this can support healthy exploration, it can also lead to fragmentation or performance anxiety. Turkle has also documented how digital communication changes our relationship with solitude and authentic self-reflection.

James Marcia's identity statuses (identity diffusion, foreclosure, moratorium, and achievement) can be applied to digital identity development. Social media may facilitate identity exploration but can also promote premature foreclosure when strong online identities form before adequate exploration.

danah boyd's (styled lowercase) research on networked publics identifies key features of digital environments: persistence (content remains), replicability (content can be copied), scalability (potential for wide audiences), and searchability (content can be found). These features fundamentally alter the context in which identity is performed and perceived.

keyTerms.dramaturgical theory: Goffman's view of social life as performance with front and back stage behaviour
keyTerms.networked publics: boyd's term for communities and audiences created by digital networks
keyTerms.context collapse: When multiple audiences that would normally be separate encounter the same content

sections.title: The Political Economy of Digital Platforms
sections.content:
Understanding digital identity requires examining the economic structures of platforms on which identities are constructed.

Social media platforms are businesses designed to generate profit, primarily through advertising. The attention economy model means platforms are designed to maximise time spent and engagement, regardless of user wellbeing. Understanding this helps explain many design features that affect identity.

Shoshana Zuboff's concept of surveillance capitalism describes how platforms extract value from user data. Our digital identities are not just self-expressions but also data profiles used for prediction and influence. Every interaction generates data that is analysed, packaged, and sold.

This creates an asymmetry of power and knowledge: platforms know far more about users than users know about platforms. Personal data becomes a form of capital, but individuals have limited control over how it's used.

The platform economy also affects identity through commodification. Online identities become brands to be cultivated and monetised. The influencer economy exemplifies this, but all users participate in a system where self-presentation has economic dimensions.

Understanding these structures enables more critical engagement with digital platforms rather than accepting their design as neutral or inevitable.

keyTerms.attention economy: An economic model where human attention is a scarce resource to be monetised
keyTerms.surveillance capitalism: An economic system based on extracting and commodifying personal data
keyTerms.commodification: The process of turning something into a product to be bought and sold

sections.title: Digital Citizenship and Collective Responsibility
sections.content:
Digital citizenship extends beyond individual safety practices to include collective responsibility for the online environment.

Individual approaches to digital identity often focus on personal protection and reputation management. While important, this framing can overlook how online environments are collectively constructed and how individual actions affect others.

Digital citizenship involves:
- Ethical engagement: Treating others with respect and considering the impact of your online actions on individuals and communities
- Active contribution: Creating positive content and supporting healthy online spaces rather than just avoiding harm
- Critical participation: Understanding how platforms work and advocating for better design and policies
- Civic engagement: Using digital tools to participate in democratic processes and social change

Bystander intervention in digital spaces is an important aspect of digital citizenship. When witnessing online harassment or misinformation, passive observation enables harm. Upstander behaviour - speaking up, reporting, and supporting targets - helps create safer environments.

Collective action can also address systemic issues. Advocacy for stronger privacy laws, ethical design standards, and platform accountability represents digital citizenship at a broader level.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives on collective responsibility offer valuable insights for digital citizenship. Concepts of reciprocity and care for community can inform more relational approaches to online behaviour.

keyTerms.digital citizenship: Responsible, ethical, and engaged participation in digital spaces
keyTerms.upstander: Someone who speaks up or takes action when witnessing harm
keyTerms.collective responsibility: Shared obligation for the health of communities and environments

sections.title: Privacy, Data Rights, and Digital Autonomy
sections.content:
Privacy in digital contexts involves complex questions about autonomy, consent, and rights that go beyond simple protection of information.

Historically, privacy was conceptualised as protection from intrusion - keeping personal matters from public view. Digital environments require expanded understanding: informational privacy (control over personal data), decisional privacy (freedom from manipulation), and contextual integrity (information flows appropriate to context).

Helen Nissenbaum's theory of contextual integrity suggests that privacy violations occur when information flows in ways inappropriate to their original context. Sharing something with friends is different from having it appear in a different context to different audiences.

Consent in digital spaces is problematic. Terms of service are designed to be unread; consent to data collection is often coerced (accept or don't use the service); and the implications of data use are often unknowable. Meaningful consent requires understanding and genuine choice - conditions rarely met in digital environments.

Digital autonomy - the capacity to make meaningful choices about your digital life - is constrained by these structures. Developing autonomy requires both individual skills (critical digital literacy, privacy practices) and structural changes (regulation, platform reform).

In Australia, privacy is partially protected by the Privacy Act and the work of the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner. Young people have specific protections through the eSafety Commissioner. Understanding these frameworks helps in advocating for stronger digital rights.

keyTerms.contextual integrity: The idea that privacy relates to appropriate information flow within contexts
keyTerms.digital autonomy: The capacity to make meaningful choices about one's digital life
keyTerms.informed consent: Agreement based on adequate understanding of implications

caseStudy.title: The Data Dilemma
caseStudy.scenario: A popular social media app used by many Australian teenagers has been found to be collecting extensive data including location, browsing history, and biometric data (like how you type and swipe). This data is shared with third parties for advertising and reportedly with government agencies in other countries. The app is very popular for connecting with friends and participating in trends. Some users are concerned and deleting the app; others say they have 'nothing to hide' and the app provides genuine value. Schools are debating whether to ban the app.

characters.name: Year 10 Student Representative Council
characters.background: Asked to develop a position on the app for their school community

questions.question: Analyse this situation using the concept of surveillance capitalism. How does the platform's business model affect its relationship with users?
questions.guidanceNote: Connect data extraction to advertising revenue and user manipulation

questions.question: Evaluate the 'nothing to hide' argument from the perspective of contextual integrity and digital autonomy.
questions.guidanceNote: Challenge the simplicity of 'nothing to hide' with nuanced privacy concepts

questions.question: What are the individual and collective dimensions of this issue? What responsibilities exist at different levels?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider individual choice, peer pressure, platform responsibility, and regulatory needs

questions.question: Develop a position that the Student Representative Council could present to the school community.
questions.guidanceNote: Look for nuanced position that acknowledges benefits, concerns, and multiple stakeholders

caseStudy.followUp: The Student Council developed a position that avoided simple prohibition, instead advocating for education about data practices, support for students choosing to leave the platform, and a letter to the company requesting better privacy practices. They also proposed a school community discussion about digital rights.

remember.question: Explain Goffman's dramaturgical theory and how it applies to social media.
remember.sampleAnswer: Goffman's dramaturgical theory views social life as performance, with 'front stage' behaviour performed for audiences and 'back stage' behaviour in private. Applied to social media, posts and profiles represent front stage performances for followers, while private messages or offline life represent back stage. Social media intensifies this dynamic because performances are permanent, audiences are multiple and often collapsed together, and the boundaries between front and back stage become blurred.

understand.question: Explain the concept of surveillance capitalism and how it affects digital identity.
understand.sampleAnswer: Surveillance capitalism, as described by Shoshana Zuboff, is an economic system where human experience is translated into behavioural data for prediction and profit. Digital platforms extract value from every user action, building detailed profiles used for advertising and influence. This affects digital identity because our online selves become data products - analysed, predicted, and monetised. The profiles platforms build of us may influence what we see, limiting our autonomy in identity development. We become both the users of platforms and the raw material for their profit.

apply.question: Apply the concept of contextual integrity to analyse a specific example of privacy violation online.
apply.sampleAnswer: Example: A student's social media photo from a party is used by a news outlet without permission to illustrate an article about teenage drinking. Using contextual integrity: the photo was shared in the context of social media for friends, with norms appropriate to that context (casual sharing among peers). The news use violates contextual integrity because information has flowed to a completely different context (public media) with different norms (journalism, public interest) and different audiences (general public). Even though the original photo was 'public' on social media, this flow violates the reasonable expectations of the original context.

analyse.question: Analyse the tension between individual privacy protection and collective digital citizenship responsibilities.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Individual privacy protection focuses on what I can do to protect myself - privacy settings, careful sharing, data minimisation. This is important but limited: it places the burden on individuals, assumes informed choice is possible, and doesn't address structural problems. Collective digital citizenship focuses on shared responsibility for online environments and advocacy for systemic change. However, collective action is harder to mobilise and results are uncertain. The tension is that strong individual protection can lead to 'every person for themselves' mentality, while emphasis on collective responsibility can minimise individual agency. A balanced approach recognises that individual practices matter while advocating for structural change - we should protect ourselves while working to create systems where such protection is less necessary.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of current privacy regulations and digital citizenship education in protecting young people's digital autonomy.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: Current approaches have significant limitations. Privacy regulations like Australia's Privacy Act provide some protection but weren't designed for the digital age and struggle with global platforms. Age verification requirements are easily bypassed and create their own privacy issues. The eSafety Commissioner provides valuable resources but can't address business models designed to exploit attention. Digital citizenship education often focuses on individual behaviour without adequately addressing structural issues - teaching students to 'be safe' without examining why platforms are designed to be unsafe. More effective approaches would include: privacy-by-design requirements for platforms, meaningful consent mechanisms, education that develops critical understanding of platform economics, and youth voices in policy development. Some progress is being made, but young people's digital autonomy remains significantly constrained by the attention economy.

create.question: Design a digital citizenship framework for Australian schools that addresses both individual and structural dimensions of digital identity.
create.sampleAnswer: Framework: 'Empowered Digital Citizens' 1) Critical Understanding: Curriculum covering how platforms work economically, surveillance capitalism, algorithmic influence, and data rights - not just 'online safety.' 2) Practical Skills: Privacy protection techniques, but framed within understanding of their limitations; media literacy including identifying manipulation. 3) Ethical Engagement: Developing shared norms for respectful online behaviour; upstander training; creating positive content. 4) Collective Action: Channels for students to advocate for platform improvements; connections to digital rights organisations; participation in policy discussions. 5) Wellbeing Integration: Understanding relationships between digital habits and mental health; developing healthy boundaries. 6) Indigenous Perspectives: Incorporating collectivist approaches to responsibility and community care. Implementation would include teacher professional development, age-appropriate progression, parent involvement, and regular updates as technology changes.

unistructural.question: Define 'surveillance capitalism'.
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Surveillance capitalism is an economic system where human experience is extracted as data for analysis, prediction, and profit by digital platforms.

multistructural.question: List three features of networked publics identified by danah boyd and explain each briefly.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Three features are: 1) Persistence - content remains available online rather than disappearing after the moment; 2) Replicability - digital content can be easily copied and spread beyond its original context; 3) Searchability - content can be found through search functions, making it difficult to control who encounters it.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between the attention economy, platform design, and digital identity development.
relational.sampleAnswer: The attention economy creates profit from capturing user attention, which drives platform design decisions. Platforms are designed with features like infinite scroll, notifications, and variable rewards that maximise engagement. These design choices shape the environment in which digital identity develops. Users are incentivised to create content that generates engagement, which may not align with authentic self-expression. The constant feedback through likes and comments can make self-worth dependent on metrics. Algorithmic content selection shapes what users see as normal or aspirational. Thus, the economic model of platforms creates design features that significantly influence how identities are formed and expressed online.

extendedAbstract.question: Propose how changes to the political economy of digital platforms might reshape digital identity development for future generations.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: Alternative economic models could fundamentally change digital identity development. If platforms were publicly funded or user-owned rather than advertising-dependent, the incentive to maximise engagement would diminish. Design could prioritise wellbeing over attention capture, reducing addictive features. Without surveillance capitalism, data collection would be minimised, allowing more contextual integrity and reducing the creation of detailed user profiles. Algorithmic recommendation could prioritise diversity over engagement, reducing filter bubbles. Identity performance could become less metric-focused if likes and followers were deprioritised. Users might develop more integrated online/offline identities without pressure to be constantly 'on.' However, challenges would remain: content moderation in decentralised systems, funding sustainable platforms, and addressing human tendencies toward social comparison that exist independent of platform design. Ultimately, economic changes are necessary but not sufficient - they must be accompanied by cultural shifts in how we value digital connection and identity expression.

prompts: How does understanding the economics of social media change how you think about your use of platforms?
What does digital citizenship mean to you? How do you practice it?
Where do you see tensions between individual privacy and participation in online communities?
How might you advocate for better digital rights and platform practices?

Developing a critical praxis for digital engagement

sections.title: Critical Theory and Digital Identity
sections.content:
Critical theory provides tools for analysing how digital technologies reproduce and transform power relations, with significant implications for identity.

The Frankfurt School's analysis of the culture industry - how mass media produces standardised culture that maintains social control - anticipates critiques of digital platforms. Platforms function as new culture industries, shaping desires, attention, and subjectivity while presenting this as free expression and connection.

Michel Foucault's concept of governmentality - the way power operates through shaping conduct rather than direct coercion - is particularly relevant. Digital platforms govern through nudges, defaults, and algorithmic management. Users internalise platform logics, disciplining their own behaviour and identity to maximise engagement.

Deleuze's 'societies of control' extends Foucault's analysis into the digital age. Unlike disciplinary societies that operated through institutions (schools, prisons, hospitals), control societies operate through continuous modulation and data. Digital identity becomes a 'dividual' - a collection of data points that can be separated, analysed, and manipulated.

Race critical theorists like Safiya Noble have demonstrated how platforms reproduce and amplify racial bias. Search algorithms reflect and reinforce racist associations. The design of digital spaces often assumes white, Western, male users as default, marginalising other identities.

Feminist technology studies examine how gender is encoded in and performed through digital technologies, and how platforms create new sites for both oppression and resistance.

keyTerms.culture industry: Frankfurt School concept of mass media as ideological control
keyTerms.governmentality: Foucault's concept of power operating through shaping conduct
keyTerms.societies of control: Deleuze's description of power through continuous modulation and data
keyTerms.dividual: The data-based profile that can be divided and manipulated

sections.title: Posthuman Digital Identities
sections.content:
Posthuman theory challenges anthropocentric assumptions about identity, with particular relevance for understanding human-technology relations.

Donna Haraway's 'Cyborg Manifesto' proposed the cyborg - a hybrid of organism and machine - as a figure for rethinking identity in technological contexts. We are all cyborgs, Haraway argued, our identities constituted through technological entanglements rather than pre-existing as natural essence.

Katherine Hayles' concept of the 'posthuman' describes how digital technologies distribute cognition beyond the individual mind. We think with our devices, remember through databases, and communicate through networks. Identity is not contained within the individual but distributed across human-machine systems.

Rosi Braidotti's nomadic posthumanism emphasises becoming over being. Rather than fixed identities, we are processes of continual transformation in relation to others, technologies, and environments. This perspective resists both technological utopianism (technology as liberation) and technological determinism (technology as control), instead examining the specific configurations of human-technology relations.

Post-digital perspectives question the distinction between online and offline, digital and physical. For those who have grown up with digital technologies, there is no separate 'digital' world - technology is simply part of the environment. This has implications for how we theorise identity: not as something with an authentic offline core corrupted by digital representation, but as always-already constituted through technological relations.

keyTerms.cyborg: Haraway's figure of human-machine hybrid identity
keyTerms.distributed cognition: The extension of cognitive processes beyond individual minds
keyTerms.nomadic subjectivity: Braidotti's concept of identity as process rather than fixed state
keyTerms.post-digital: Perspectives that move beyond online/offline distinctions

sections.title: Algorithmic Governance and Digital Futures
sections.content:
Algorithms increasingly govern social processes, with profound implications for identity, agency, and justice.

Algorithmic decision-making affects access to credit, employment, education, and justice. These systems often encode historical biases while appearing objective and neutral. Their complexity and proprietary nature make them difficult to challenge - a situation Frank Pasquale calls the 'black box society.'

Artificial intelligence raises questions about the boundaries of identity and agency. As AI systems become more sophisticated, questions arise about personhood, rights, and the uniqueness of human identity. These are not merely science fiction scenarios but present ethical challenges.

Predictive systems don't just analyse existing behaviour but shape future possibilities. When systems predict who will commit crimes, default on loans, or succeed in education, they can create self-fulfilling prophecies. The identity categories created by algorithmic systems become difficult to escape.

Data colonialism, as theorised by Nick Couldry and Ulises Mejias, describes how the extraction of human life as data continues colonial relations of appropriation. Platform capitalism extracts value from populations in ways that echo colonial extraction of resources, raising questions of justice and resistance.

Alternative digital futures are possible but require imagination and action. Indigenous data sovereignty movements, platform cooperativism, and digital rights advocacy all represent efforts to shape different technological trajectories. The future of digital identity is not determined but contested.

keyTerms.black box society: Pasquale's term for systems whose decision-making processes are hidden
keyTerms.algorithmic governance: The management of social processes through automated systems
keyTerms.data colonialism: The appropriation of human life as data in ways that continue colonial relations
keyTerms.digital sovereignty: The right of peoples to control their own digital environments and data

sections.title: Toward a Critical Digital Praxis
sections.content:
Moving from critical analysis to transformative practice requires developing what might be called a critical digital praxis - informed, reflective, and politically engaged action.

Praxis, in critical theory, refers to informed action that transforms conditions. Critical digital praxis combines understanding of platform political economy, power relations, and identity formation with committed action toward more just digital futures.

This involves multiple dimensions:

Individual practice includes critical reflection on one's own platform use, attention to how digital environments affect wellbeing and identity, and developing habits that support autonomy while remaining connected.

Collective organisation involves building communities that model alternative digital relations, supporting movements for digital rights and platform accountability, and creating counter-publics that resist dominant platform logics.

Institutional intervention includes advocating for regulation, supporting alternative platform development, and working within existing institutions (schools, workplaces) to promote critical digital literacy.

Creative production involves using digital tools for expressions that resist commodification and control, creating content that builds critical consciousness, and experimenting with alternative modes of digital relation.

The goal is not withdrawal from digital life - which is neither possible nor necessarily desirable - but engaged participation that works toward transformation. As with other critical praxes, this involves ongoing reflection, collective development, and acceptance of uncertainty about outcomes.

keyTerms.counter-publics: Alternative public spheres that resist dominant norms
keyTerms.platform cooperativism: Movement to create user-owned alternatives to corporate platforms
keyTerms.critical consciousness: Awareness of social structures and commitment to transformation

caseStudy.title: The AI Identity Challenge
caseStudy.scenario: A new AI system claims to be able to predict students' academic outcomes and 'learning styles' from their digital activity. The company wants to implement it in Australian schools, promising more efficient allocation of resources and personalised learning. Critics point out the system encodes historical biases, reduces student identity to data points, and creates self-fulfilling prophecies. Some students say they would feel reduced to algorithmic predictions; others say if it improves their education, they don't mind. Indigenous education experts raise concerns about how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students would be categorised by a system built on Western assumptions. You are asked to contribute to a policy analysis.

characters.name: Policy Analysis Team
characters.background: Multi-stakeholder team developing recommendations on algorithmic systems in education

questions.question: Analyse this situation through the lens of algorithmic governance and identity formation. What are the implications of predictive systems for student identity and agency?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider how predictions can become self-fulfilling and how categorisation limits identity possibilities

questions.question: Apply critical theory concepts to examine the power relations embedded in this system. Whose interests are served by framing education as a problem to be solved through prediction?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider governmentality, data colonialism, and the culture industry

questions.question: How do Indigenous perspectives and the concerns of Indigenous education experts challenge the assumptions of such systems?
questions.guidanceNote: Consider Western assumptions about individual achievement, data sovereignty, and alternative knowledge systems

questions.question: Develop recommendations that move toward critical digital praxis in education rather than simply accepting or rejecting the technology.
questions.guidanceNote: Look for nuanced position that addresses power relations while remaining practical

caseStudy.followUp: The policy team recommended against implementing the system as proposed, but didn't stop there. They proposed a process for developing any educational AI that centred student voice, required algorithmic transparency, included Indigenous governance structures, and began with critical digital literacy education for all stakeholders.

remember.question: Outline the key concepts of Deleuze's 'societies of control' and how they apply to digital identity.
remember.sampleAnswer: Deleuze's societies of control describe a shift from disciplinary societies (where power operated through institutions like schools and prisons) to control societies (where power operates through continuous modulation, passwords, and data). In disciplinary societies, you passed through discrete institutions; in control societies, you are continuously tracked and modulated. Applied to digital identity, individuals become 'dividuals' - collections of data points that can be separated and manipulated. Identity is not controlled through physical confinement but through data profiles that determine access and possibilities. Digital platforms exemplify control societies through continuous surveillance, algorithmic sorting, and modulated access to information and opportunities.

understand.question: Explain how posthuman theory challenges traditional concepts of digital identity.
understand.sampleAnswer: Posthuman theory challenges traditional concepts of digital identity in several ways. It rejects the assumption that identity has an authentic, pre-existing core that technology merely represents or distorts. Instead, identity is understood as constituted through relations, including human-technology relations - we are always already cyborgs. It challenges the individual as the unit of analysis, proposing distributed cognition and networked identity that extend beyond individual minds and bodies. It questions the human/machine boundary, suggesting that both are in processes of becoming rather than fixed categories. It resists both technological utopianism and dystopia, instead examining specific configurations of human-technology relations. For digital identity, this means moving beyond questions of whether online identity is 'authentic' toward understanding how identity is continually produced through technological entanglements.

apply.question: Apply the concept of data colonialism to analyse a specific digital platform's practices.
apply.sampleAnswer: Platform: Facebook/Meta. Data colonialism involves the appropriation of human life as data in ways that continue colonial relations of extraction. Facebook colonises user data through: 1) Extraction without meaningful consent - users 'agree' to complex terms to participate in social life, generating vast data about relationships, preferences, and behaviours. 2) Asymmetric value creation - user data generates enormous profits for shareholders while users receive services rather than fair compensation. 3) Territorial expansion - the platform constantly expands into new areas of life (VR, financial services, workplace tools), colonising ever more of human experience. 4) Resistance to local governance - the platform operates globally while resisting national regulation, echoing colonial disregard for local sovereignty. 5) Creation of dependency - by becoming essential infrastructure for social and business life, the platform creates relations of dependency. Like historical colonialism, this involves exploitation through asymmetric power relations while being framed as beneficial ('connecting the world').

analyse.question: Analyse the relationship between critical consciousness and algorithmic subjectivity in contemporary digital environments.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Critical consciousness - awareness of social structures and commitment to transformation - exists in tension with algorithmic subjectivity - identity shaped through platform logics and data profiles. Algorithms shape attention, information exposure, and social feedback, influencing what becomes thinkable. Filter bubbles and recommendation systems can reinforce existing views rather than promote critical examination. Platform design encourages engagement over reflection, fast reactions over slow thinking. The 'dividual' nature of algorithmic identity reduces persons to manipulable data points, potentially undermining the unified subject that critical consciousness assumes. However, this relationship is not simply antagonistic. Digital tools can also support critical consciousness: enabling access to critical analysis, connecting geographically dispersed movements, exposing inequities through viral documentation. Critical digital praxis involves developing consciousness of algorithmic operations while using digital tools for critical purposes. The challenge is maintaining reflective distance and critical capacity within environments designed to capture attention and shape behaviour.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the possibilities and limitations of platform cooperativism as an alternative to surveillance capitalism.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: Platform cooperativism - user-owned alternatives to corporate platforms - offers genuine possibilities while facing significant limitations. Possibilities: It addresses the root cause of platform problems by changing ownership and incentive structures. User-owned platforms can prioritise wellbeing over engagement, privacy over data extraction. They model alternative relations of production in the digital economy. Successful examples exist (Stocksy, Up&Go). They connect to broader movements for economic democracy. Limitations: Network effects make it hard to compete with established platforms - a cooperative social network is only valuable if others use it. Startup capital is harder to raise without promise of extractive returns. User-owned governance is complex and time-consuming. Cooperatives still operate within capitalist markets and are pressured to adopt competitive practices. They don't address state surveillance or broader power structures. Evaluation: Platform cooperativism is valuable as prefigurative politics - modelling alternative relations - and as a reform strategy that can improve specific services. However, it's insufficient as a complete solution to surveillance capitalism, which requires broader political-economic transformation including regulation, public alternatives, and changed social relations beyond platforms.

create.question: Develop a framework for critical digital praxis that integrates individual, collective, and structural dimensions.
create.sampleAnswer: Framework: 'Entangled Digital Praxis' Foundations: Posthuman recognition that we are always already in technological relations; critical theory understanding of platform power; commitment to transformation rather than withdrawal. Individual Dimension: Critical reflection on platform use (what is extracted, how identity is shaped); practices of attention management; selective engagement based on values; creation of private spaces for reflection; ongoing self-education about digital systems. Collective Dimension: Building communities that model alternative digital relations; supporting digital rights movements; developing shared analysis of platform impacts; mutual aid in navigating digital challenges; creating counter-narratives and counter-publics. Institutional/Structural Dimension: Advocating for regulation (privacy, algorithmic transparency, competition); supporting alternative platform development; promoting critical digital literacy in education; resisting normalisation of surveillance; engaging with policy processes. Integration: These dimensions are connected - individual practices support collective capacity; collective action creates institutional change; structural change enables new individual possibilities. The framework is iterative - actions generate learning that refines analysis and practice. Praxis involves embracing uncertainty while maintaining commitment; accepting complicity while working toward transformation; acting within existing conditions while imagining alternatives.

unistructural.question: Define 'algorithmic governance'.
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Algorithmic governance refers to the management and control of social processes through automated computational systems that make or influence decisions affecting people's lives.

multistructural.question: Identify three key concepts from critical theory that can be applied to analyse digital platforms.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Three key concepts are: 1) The culture industry - platforms as producers of standardised culture that maintains social control; 2) Governmentality - platforms operating power through shaping conduct rather than direct coercion; 3) Societies of control - continuous modulation and surveillance through data replacing disciplinary institutions.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between posthuman theory and understanding digital identity in the contemporary world.
relational.sampleAnswer: Posthuman theory and digital identity are closely connected because posthuman perspectives help overcome limitations of traditional identity concepts. Traditional theory assumed a bounded individual with an authentic core that technology might distort or represent. Posthuman theory instead sees identity as constituted through relations, including technological relations - we think with devices, remember through databases, exist in networks. This perspective helps us understand digital identity not as a separate 'online self' versus 'real self' but as always emerging through human-technology entanglements. It shifts focus from authenticity (is this the 'real' person?) to configurations (what relations and possibilities does this arrangement create?). Digital platforms become not external tools we use but constitutive elements of identity formation. This has ethical implications - responsibility becomes distributed, and change requires attending to technological arrangements, not just individual choices.

extendedAbstract.question: Synthesise critical theory, posthuman approaches, and Indigenous perspectives to propose an alternative paradigm for understanding digital identity.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: An alternative paradigm would integrate multiple perspectives while transforming each through encounter with others. From critical theory: Recognition that digital identity is produced within power relations - platforms are not neutral but shape subjectivity in ways that serve capital. Analysis must attend to who benefits and who is harmed by particular arrangements. From posthuman approaches: Identity is always already technological and distributed - there is no authentic pre-digital self to protect. This resists both technological utopianism and nostalgia. It enables attention to specific configurations rather than general claims about technology's effects. From Indigenous perspectives: Relational ontologies that have always understood identity as constituted through connections - to Country, kin, ancestors. This provides resources for thinking digital identity beyond Western individualism. Concepts of reciprocity, collective responsibility, and data sovereignty offer ethical frameworks for digital relations. Synthesis: Digital identity as relational becoming within power-laden technological configurations. Neither purely constructed (no constraints) nor determined (no agency). Subject to critical analysis of power relations while open to transformation through collective action. Grounded in specific relationships and responsibilities rather than abstract principles. Oriented toward justice while accepting uncertainty and ongoing struggle. This paradigm neither celebrates nor condemns technology but engages critically with specific arrangements, working within existing conditions while imagining alternatives.

prompts: How has engaging with critical theory perspectives changed how you think about your own digital identity?
What does the concept of being 'always already' entangled with technology mean for understanding authenticity?
What forms of resistance to surveillance capitalism seem most promising to you? What are their limitations?
How might Indigenous perspectives on relationality inform your own digital praxis?
What would it mean to practice critical digital praxis in your own life?
